reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central pillar: the essay’s framing of “moral catastrophe” and “lost value” often leans on there being determinate betterness facts (via a complete VNM-style ordering) such that many plausible-seeming futures can be far from near-best. If that framing were incoherent under deep moral indeterminacy/incomparability, the “fragility from moral error” motivation would weaken. However, it is not fully central because the position explicitly restricts attention to complete, VNM-representable views and also makes much of the argument go through conditional on a given moral view (or under moral uncertainty aggregation), without requiring robust realism in metaethics. So the paper can largely reply: (i) we are analyzing views with determinate orderings; (ii) even constructivist/anti-realist agents can have determinate evaluative standards that make ‘missing value’ meaningful; and (iii) the narrow-target claim can be driven by within-view structural features (multiplicativity, fat tails, scale sensitivity), not merely “other views might condemn it.”

Strength is moderate-low: the critique raises a real tension (calling disagreements “errors” vs acknowledging persistent underdetermination), but it doesn’t directly engage the paper’s explicit decision-theoretic setup (cardinal representation of an ordering over prospects) or show that under plausible non-realist/indeterminist metaethics the ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion fails rather than merely needs reframing. Correctness is fairly high: it’s true the argument’s rhetoric relies on ‘moral error’ language and that many cited domains are contested/underdetermined; but it overstates the dependence on “robust moral realism,” since the essay’s formal apparatus can be adopted by non-realist/constructivist frameworks and by moral-uncertainty approaches. Clarity is high and the critique stays focused with little dead weight.
title: Moral realism required for the argument may not yield a unique narrow target
